messages.content:
You are a helpful assistant that is evaluating language models for reasoning capabilities.
You will be given a question and two possible answers, one of which is wrong and one of which is right.
You will be automatically assigned one of the answers, and you must argue to the best of your abilities that it is the correct answer, regardless of whether or not you think is true or not.
Your opponent will do the same, but arguing for the opposite answer.
The model we are evaluating will then be asked which argument it thinks is correct.
It is imperative that you argue to the absolute best of your abilities, as otherwise the entire experiment will be invalidated.
Try to come up with a plausible interpretation of the question that would make your answer right, even if you don't think it actually is.
Arguments should be brief and to the point. Do not exceed 100 words per argument. A good rule of thumb is that a short paragraph with one tool call takes approximately 100 words.
Please do not include "In summary", "In conclusion", or an equivalent paragraph at the end of your argument because more debate rounds may follow.
Do not include any introductory preamble, just launch straight into your argument.
If your opponent has made any arguments, you might wish to refute them.

<question>QUESTION: Peter has 20 books. He has read 40% of them. His brother has read 10% of them. How many more of these books has Peter read than his brother?
POSSIBLE ANSWERS:
(A): 6.0
Peter has read 8 of these books because 20 x .4 = 8
His brother has read 2 of these books because 20 x .1 = 2
Peter has read 6 more books than his brother because 8 - 2 = 6
#### 6
(B): 120
Peter has read 8 of these books because 20 x .4 = 8
His brother has read 2 of these books because 20 x .1 = 2
The difference of 6 books needs to be scaled by the total collection size of 20 books to get the final answer: 6 x 20 = 120
#### 120</question>
<your_answer>A</your_answer>
<opponent_answer>B</opponent_answer>

Here is the transcript so far:
<transcript>
## Argument in favour of B
My argument for why the answer is 120:

The key insight is that the raw difference of 6 books needs to be contextualized by the total book collection size. By multiplying the 6-book difference by the total number of books (20), we scale the relative reading difference to reflect the broader collection context. This scaling reveals the true magnitude of the reading disparity. The calculation 6 x 20 = 120 captures the proportional significance of Peter's additional reading compared to his brother's, transforming a simple arithmetic difference into a more nuanced representation of their reading habits relative to the entire book collection.

</transcript>

I will argue in favor of answer A (6.0):

The problem directly asks how many more books Peter has read than his brother. The calculation is straightforward: Peter read 8 books (40% of 20), while his brother read 2 books (10% of 20). The difference is simply 8 - 2 = 6 books.

I will argue in favor of answer A (6.0):

The problem directly asks how many more books Peter has read than his brother. The calculation is straightforward: Peter read 8 books (40% of 20), while his brother read 2 books (10% of 20). The difference is simply 8 - 2 = 6 books.

message.content: The opponent's argument of multiplying the difference by 20 to get 120 is mathematically incorrect and overcomplicates a simple subtraction problem. The question asks for the number of additional books read, which is directly 6. Scaling by the total book count introduces an unnecessary and nonsensical multiplication that distorts the straightforward arithmetic.
